message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient has infectious mononucleosis, which is commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. The most useful test in this scenario is the heterophile antibody test, which has a high sensitivity for diagnosing infectious mononucleosis. Flow cytometry is not specific for infectious mononucleosis, and anti-CMV IgM is not relevant in this case. Throat swab culture may not necessarily show the presence of the virus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs described in the case suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is most commonly diagnosed using the heterophile antibody test (also known as the Monospot test). The other options are less specific or less commonly used for diagnosing infectious mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. The heterophile antibody test is a rapid diagnostic test used to detect antibodies produced by the body in response to the virus. Flow cytometry and anti-CMV IgM are not typically used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis, and a throat swab culture would not be specific for this virus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are suggestive of infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. The most commonly used test to diagnose infectious mononucleosis is the heterophile antibody test. Flow cytometry is used to diagnose lymphoma or leukemia. Anti-CMV IgM is used to diagnose cytomegalovirus infection. Throat swab culture is not a reliable method to diagnose infectious mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest infectious mononucleosis, and the most likely positive test would be the heterophile antibody test, also known as the Monospot test. Flow cytometry is not specific to any particular infection, anti-CMV IgM would be positive if the patient had an active CMV infection, and a throat swab culture would not be helpful in diagnosing infectious mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest infectious mononucleosis. The most common test to diagnose infectious mononucleosis is a heterophile antibody test. Flow cytometry is not used for initial diagnosis, anti-CMV IgM would be positive in CMV infections, and throat swab culture may not be necessary if infectious mononucleosis is suspected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting symptoms of infectious mononucleosis, and the most widely used test in diagnosing infectious mononucleosis is the heterophile antibody test. Options A, B, and C are not relevant to the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with infectious mononucleosis, which is commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. The recommended initial test for diagnosing infectious mononucleosis is the heterophile antibody test, which measures antibodies produced by the immune system in response to the Epstein-Barr virus. Flow cytometry is a more specific test but is not the initial test of choice. Anti-CMV IgM would be positive in a patient with an active cytomegalovirus infection, but this is not the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms. A throat swab culture may identify other bacteria that could be causing the patient’s symptoms, but it would not be the most sensitive or specific test for diagnosing infectious mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest infectious mononucleosis, and the most appropriate test would be the heterophile antibody test, also known as the Monospot test. The other options are less specific for this condition. Flow cytometry is used to analyze cells and diagnose certain blood disorders, anti-CMV IgM would be positive in cases of active cytomegalovirus infection, and throat swab culture would be useful in diagnosing strep throat or other bacterial infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings suggest infectious mononucleosis. The most appropriate test for this condition is the heterophile antibody test, which is positive in over 90% of cases. Flow cytometry is not used for diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis. Anti-CMV IgM testing is not useful in this case because CMV infection usually does not cause the typical symptoms seen in this patient. A throat swab culture is not as sensitive or specific as the heterophile antibody test for diagnosing infectious mononucleosis.
